unnormalised: AIIMS Delhi has announced a new initiative to improve oncology care access for patients from underserved regions. Apparently, many patients from states like Bihar & UP struggle to get timely appointments, leading to delays in crucial treatments. The hospital plans to set up telemedicine clinics in these areas, connecting patients with Dr. Gupta's oncology team for initial consultations.
normalised: A-I-I-M-S Delhi has announced a new initiative to improve oncology care access for patients from underserved regions. Apparently, many patients from states like Bihar and U-P struggle to get timely appointments, leading to delays in crucial treatments. The hospital plans to set up telemedicine clinics in these areas, connecting patients with Doctor Gupta's oncology team for initial consultations.

unnormalised: The initiative aims to reduce the waiting time, which is currently around 2-3 months for a first appointment. Telemedicine consults will help prioritize urgent cases. Patients requiring immediate attention can be referred directly for admission or specialized procedures like radiation therapy. A pilot program is scheduled to start on 15/07/2024.
normalised: The initiative aims to reduce the waiting time, which is currently around two to three months for a first appointment. Telemedicine consults will help prioritize urgent cases. Patients requiring immediate attention can be referred directly for admission or specialized procedures like radiation therapy. A pilot program is scheduled to start on fifteenth july two thousand and twenty four.

unnormalised: "We are committed to providing the best possible care," said Dr. Sharma, head of oncology at AIIMS. "This initiative is a step towards ensuring that everyone, regardless of their location, has access to timely and quality cancer treatment. Early detection and timely treatment are key to improving survival rates. For instance, a patient with Stage 1 breast cancer has a significantly better prognosis than someone diagnosed at Stage 4. Even something as simple as a mammogram, costing approximately Rs. 2500, can make a huge difference.”
normalised: "We are committed to providing the best possible care," said Doctor Sharma, head of oncology at A-I-I-M-S. "This initiative is a step towards ensuring that everyone, regardless of their location, has access to timely and quality cancer treatment. Early detection and timely treatment are key to improving survival rates. For instance, a patient with Stage one breast cancer has a significantly better prognosis than someone diagnosed at Stage four. Even something as simple as a mammogram, costing approximately rupees two thousand five hundred, can make a huge difference.”
